e0Dnwj4jQeuLZhNSSPtnpg.text: Stumbled across this gem of a pub when they had one of their regular 3 courses for £18 on top table. So glad I did as we now go for dinner every Sunday. Even without the promo the food as well as being out of this world like you would expect in any ramsay restaurant is fabulous value for money, Have taken my parents, my best friends and our grown up children and must have covered every item on the menu between us and can not find a bad word to say about any of it.The pigeon with crispy bacon and quail egg is my fav starter totally delicious. All the fish dishes are amazing but the hake and chips will have you never wanting fish and chips from anywhere else again it is simply to die for, the chips are always just amazing sounds nuts over chips but they are divine crispy on the outside and so soft and hot on the inside you have to try them to know what I am talking about!Other favourite is the hanger steak. And deserts the eton cherry mess and banana split are scrumptious. Service always fantastic as you would expect, Andrei is totally amazing has been our server every week and has a fabulous knowledge of champagnes, which incidentally are very good prices for London, if you want something more special special they have some vintages and houses not on the menu like 99 cristal.The decor of course excellent the atmosphere fantastic and as for the view over the Thames brilliant. As you would expect for such a great value place they often get fully booked at weekends so booking is essential but if online says they are full is always worth giving a call. As have managed to squeeze me in on these occasions. To sum up fabulous.Would also say is pretty obvious that several of the reviews on here are total nonsense besides the lady below who actually states she did not eat there there seem to be several 1 star comments from people who have never written a review before, I get the feeling that other empty pubs and restaurants near by with plenty of time on their hands due to competition from the narrow which they can't possibly match have signed up just to try and smear what is an outstanding place, am sure people on here have enough intelligence to see through this, and if u doubt have a look at reviews on top table where you have actually had to eat there(by booking through them) to leave a review as you would expect not one complaint on there!!Love at first bite

fRDeX7JmTXVI_fmAlaqmUA.text: When I first heard that foul-mouth chef Gordon Ramsay was opening a pub [he's since opened two more], I knew I would have to try it out. The Narrow, his East London enterprise, didn't disappoint. Just south of Lime House DLR and hard along the Thames, this is a handsome, stylish, smartly managed pub with surprisingly good food and absolutely no attitude. I came in after the lunch rush and was warmly welcomed [as a party of one] and seated in the dining room with a lovely view of the Thames. I ordered clam chowder, banger and mash and a local brew from Greenwich. None of it disappointed. The service was spot-on; the staff outgoing. You can whatever you want about GR's manner and tone but you can't argue with the food or service. Top notch.

2bEPJ1uhhmBbzn3gD8vnYQ.text: fantastic hangout to grab beer and food along the water.  I hear it's great spot in the summer.  the pork cheeks, bangers and mash, and fish/chips were fantastic.  there's a parking garage next door so you don't have to worry about street parking.

Lv7G7oNpK5jdaJ0A3BtZDg.text: We ate here yesterday on a gorgeous sunny day which ehances one of the main attractions of The Narrow - the fantastic Thames view. Lovely for our kids who went and sat on deckchairs on the walkway whilst we waited for drinks (must say a very child-friendly crowd for such a chic looking eaterie). Like most people on here I thought the staff were lovely and althogh it may not be any deliberate policy the fact that they were all shapes, sizes and nationalities instead of models from Casting Central was brilliant. I have probably just been libellious. The food itself was ok. my pork was fantastic but the veggies were overdone a bit but it was just a great trip on a lovely summer's evening.

lg4zM91y70EkQbMXyGDFtA.text: This is what I would expect from a Gordon Ramsay gastropub -- great food, laid back, excellent service. Not a single person at our had any problems with their starters or mains except that we wanted more. The fish dishes deserve special acclaim as they truly were cooked to perfection: great colour, tender, with all the natural tastes of fish oozing out. One particular surprise was the deliciousness of the roasted potatoes; fluffy insides were covered by a nicely browned skin, slightly crispy and not overly oily. Everyone who tried them were delighted by this simple treat. Speaking of treats, dessert is not to be missed! Chocolate cake, gypsy tarts and ice cream. I selected a brilliantly subtle elderflower jelly with summer fruits. We were practically licking our plates at the end. A great experience all around and I'll definitely be going back.

B-HsXLGO97iDrwOE4N13xg.text: Situated just by the Thames 5 minutes from Limehouse DLR, it's not in the most attractive location. This however, doesn't matter as the pub is everything you'd expect frmo a typical English pub. But perhaps that is also where the problem lies, there is nothing outstanding about it. The food is good and reasonably priced, and there are plenty of beers on tap and bottled. However, the whole attachment of 'Ramsey' to the place just makes clients expect a little more? As a pub it's excellent, with Ramseys name attached I expected a little more.

z27DbkCEzh3SCTqoMrjRoQ.text: great view from riverside seating IF YOU HAVE RESERVED!! The menu looked plain and to have to order veg to go with your main course at £3.50 each WOW 12.5% service charge for poor to nil service is cheeky £15 for a pitcher of pimms which was 90% ice and fruit is a con. After reading that some Ramsey places had meals delivered I am almost sure that Tesco home delivery was around the back for my meal??

uHpw61xOw7iNIucggj9iug.text: Over-rated remake of what was once a fantastic place to grab a pint in the summer. Disappointing food: high price for thoroughly mediocre fare and smallish portions. If this is the result of a Gordon Ramsey takeover, I'll be sure to stay away from his other ventures. Patrons would be far better served for food and drink by heading to the Grapes nearby-if you can get in, that is.

1AaG957PhabBS3wQEr-ZEQ.text: Location: Limehouse (Which at first I thought was a bit random) but the location is beautiful, we were lucky that the weather was nice as it is right on the water.  We sat in the conservatory area.  There is a bar and an indoor restaurant area. Service: The service was about a 7/10Food: I am a vegetarian, and there is 1 vegetarian main on the menu, which nowadays is quite rare.  The 1 main was lentils.  I am sorry but lentils is the most boring food ever, now being that Gordon is so well known you would have thought that there would have been a bit more imagination put into that main, since when did any pub sell lentils??I asked if they cooked something else, and the waiter said "no" so in the end, I ordered food from the bar.  The main I had was mushrooms on toast with a poached egg, with a side of green beans and chips.  The food was really tasty and the chips were really nice.  For dessert we were told that the sticky toffee pudding (Which we all wanted funny enough) was not available :( so I opted for raspberry tart and hazelnut ice cream, it was lovely, the ice cream was really tasty.  My friend had the chocolate mousse, which was also very nice. Price: The prices seem a bit high, but that could be down to location.  Evaluation: I wouldn't go again, only due to the lack of veggie options, if they ramped up the menu a bit more, then I would def go again, but only on a sunny day :)

MQu3DR01jgoBUouFX7AUCw.text: Great location overlooking the Thames, quaint historic building.   Good "elevated" bistro-pub grub, unenthusiastic service..

4WdyNHzYCKGY9a1P9v-FZQ.text: The odd thing is, The Narrow should be a joy. Located right on the edge of the river, huge outside deck, big windows if you can't sit outside. We headed there mid week mid summer for lunch on a sparklingly sunny day. Oddly, even though it was about 1pm there was almost no punters. Bought a couple of pints, grabbed a copy of both the restaurant and bar menus and headed out to soak up the sun. A selection from the starters to share sounded most interesting so asked for them at the bar only to be told that they could only be served inside in the restaurant, which had possibly 8 diners in total. Only food from the bar menu was available outside. Okay, we'll spend less but am happy to try scotch eggs, smoked potato cakes and steamed mussels and a pea & broad bean salad. No. Turns out all they have available to serve from the bar menu is cheeseburger or a BLT. Absolutely nothing else. So we left. Rentamob staff who couldn't give a toss rounded out a perfectly awful experience. It's the kind of place that would go down a storm on Kitchen Nightmares...

okINCmXhTP7DPzgdlU5YBg.text: Went with a group of friends on a Summer evening and everything was spot on.  Nice view, friendly staff, good wine & beer, solid food.  Everyone was very pleased and we had a great time.  I had the braised pork cheek and I thought it was out of this world.  Perfectly cooked.  Only complaint was that it was tough to get home from (back to Waterloo) when it got late.  We missed the last boat :(

go6LgxK6plZL88AlhF8jcw.text: I will base this on my recent return to the narrow after around 2 years totally chaned for the good.Lovely fish and chips and the wife had the mac cheese which I usually don't like but was so nice I kept stealing Hers. Excellent value for the pound and nice friendly service will bs back a lit sooner then 2 years

bWjwUMDdkdWCFD0UyqwrMA.text: Situated on the edge of the Thames, you couldn't ask for a better location for a meal with friends, family or a hot date. The food is gastropub style and of a fairly good quality, but somewhat over priced. Good venue for a special occasion

Gsng36H7b9zWtCmAyM7-GQ.text: Usually stop here when I'm guiltily watching people run the London marathon whilst sipping a pint. It's pretty average and on my last visit the bar said they had run out of Pimms, when in fact there was a bottle on the shelf they'd had just run out of all the trimmings which is quite frankly not good enough on a bank holiday weekend as you would expect someone (Gordon Ramsey) to have the initiative to order extra mint, strawberries, cucumber etc! Loos are pretty horrid too. But there's a nice conservatory and view of the Thames.

lqibRSU-6hCpZ-9SdKa38Q.text: What a superb place to spend some time, I was recommended by a very well travelled friend who writes a where to Eat and drink for one of England's finer newspapers, From setting foot in the narrow one was made to feel like you were joining your own family for dinner, The beautiful view of the Thames was only surpassed by the excellent food and service. After getting used to the outrageous prices of many so called Gastro Pubs that have popped up over and around London The Narrow is a real Breath Of fresh Air, and terrific Value.To sum up Food that you would expect in any Ramsay establishment combined with the warmth and friendliness not often found in London Pubs and amazing value my nomination for Michelin's Pub of the Year

cyX6IwgO0Nu6VN6KSVvtGQ.text: I was staying in Canary Wharf on a recent trip to London, and I was very curious about "The Narrow", the Gordon Ramsay pub nearby. Very interested to see what kind of establishment the uber-critic would run!I went by on a Wednesday evening round 8:00, and the place was active, but certainly not crowded. The bar was more-or-less empty and there were groups of diners in the large dining area. I was seated without any problem, but -- the bane of the solo diner! -- I was hidden away in an obscure corner of the restaurant. The menu choices consisted of a variety of Pub staples, and I chose a couple of traditional choices (again curious to see how standard Pub grub would be served in Ramsay's place.) I started with a very good Belgian lager and potato-leek soup. Both were very good -- the soup, in particular, was excellent. I followed up with the Bangers and Mash, and a side of green beans. The sausages and potatoes were tasty and satisfying, if a little boring as a main dish (but then again, I suppose if you ask for Bangers and Mash, that's what it is...) The green beans were very fresh and nicely crunchy. Service was very friendly and attentive, and in general, I had a very satisfying meal.Also, probably a little bit more expensive than an average pub meal, but really very reasonably priced. Definitely a place to go back to on a future trip for a tasteful twist on your typical pub meal...!

0d8UNp0fkZwEZousb9gJSA.text: We had Sunday Roast which was alright.  The Yorkshire puding was our favorite part of the meal.  I love the location of this restaurant right on the Thames.  We look forward to going back.

1AgkJS9tu0mertdPw9tklw.text: I just got back to the States from spending some time in Europe and I spent several evenings here.  It was FANTASTIC!!  The view was KILLER and the food amazing.  I met a lot of great folks each time I went, everything/everyone was great!

BCNvUWoZpk7BJRFqIo6vLg.text: A Gordon Ramsey pub. Now I hope that those of you that are not made of money didn't stop reading as soon as you read that, because it's not quite what you think. Sure I wouldn't be surprised if the food they serve would require refinancing of some kind, but the drinks were London prices, if a little over average for the area. I didn't get a great look at the inside, because outside they have a lovely deck..with one of the best river views I've seen in London, enhanced by the proximity of Canary Wharf. If you can get a spot here I'd recommend it. Although the style of pub is modern, there has been a pub on this spot for a while now (and way way back there was a brewery here). They serve a few ales. I enjoyed a pint of Adnams Regatta, which is one of my favouritesand it tasted good. I can certainly imagine coming here again, particularly with friends who might be curious about a Ramsey pub.

p3iM3ZhO_WkZlw-6MSbDKg.text: Lovely food, good location, polite (but slow) service

u15E6atXMlexwhZidpUWhg.text: I had a table on the restaurant side overlooking the Thames. They had a course and normal menu. Nothing really stood out on the course so ended up getting the braised pork cheeks with smoked applewood bacon risotto and barley. The pork was tender and moist and the risotto had fucking bacon in it so of course it was good. I had an ale called Meantime and it was pretty smooth. Although I expected to be wowed coz this was Ramsey's place but it was just OK. The main thing that impressed me was the sticky toffee pudding with toffee sauce and ice cream. Others in the group had the baked bream and the fish and chips. The fish and chips looked better than it tasted and the bream had a lemon caper sauce that made it taste better than it looked. I'd go back jus. For the beer, view and the toffee pudding. Like I said above everything else seemed just OK.

rJ9Ikbc5v9HuoTKMJHDPtg.text: What a disappointment. We encountered the Police at the front door who were apprehending someone who was shouting his head off and judging by the greeting of the staff to the officers it was quite clearly not the first time they had been there. We had to wait extra time for our table in the conservatory which looks really cheap and filled with those free standing heaters. When we finally got our table it wobbled so we asked the waiter for something to wedge under it and never received anything so used a menu instead. When ordering we were told that certain things were off the menu, but the next table that arrived after us managed to order these things. Our waiter was more interested in chatting to the other staff than trying to take our order and when our food eventually arrived we had no cutlery so we had to ask someone else for that. We didn't stay for more than a main course as we could see that it was a shambles and didn't want to waste anymore time and money. I can't quite believe Gordon Ramsay is putting his name to something like this.

D_yIXhEg2ZMxPS0vuv_dcw.text: The food and atmosphere  in this place was a real winner.  The service is crap.  Gordon should make sure his staff watches his shows.  For the price it is you should at least feel like your not forgotten.

2LyMrpeh5eup1RYdvTDtRg.text: We decided to venture out to Limehouse to try out some Gordon Ramsay cuisine without the city price tag. We were not disappointed, the dining room was cosy and warm with views out across the river. The menu was ecelectic, all very British but a mix of the standard gastro pub type options like bangers and mash (fancy ones mind) and then more alternative choices like pigs cheeks. We ordered a range of options and all had a try of each others dishes, they were all lovely and it created great discussion about food. Three courses later and many bottles of wine we all stumbled out onto the street only £30 lighter. And the journey home was brief, its not as far away as you might imagine. The only criticism is that when we moved from the restaurant to the bar to relax with another bottle of wine, they didn't note that we had moved and wouldn't put the wine onto the main bill. This didn't make much sense to us and they weren't very helpful about it. When we did then ask for the bill it took half an hour to get it as again, they were unaware that we had moved tables. Not so slick but next time I know to treat the restaurant and bar as two separate venues and pay the individual bills for each. I would still go back for the food most definitely.

lQygojBoFLxwc9BHJVdHRw.text: The Monthly Tueday Night comedy night is spot on and free entry with a really nice packed room of people and a great atmosphere. Burger and chips is yummy and they do Meantime ales

BKS72pqpJuXbVGsrKzHQvg.text: I'm a huge fan of Gordon's restaurants and The Narrow does not disappoint. Having moved from West London to the Canary Wharf area, it is nice to finally have decent gastropub offering in the area - it is something lacking in the E14 neighbourhood. The menu is quite short, but always offers imaginative dishes made from traditional British ingredients. Excellent quality ingredients, prepared simply and well - I have yet to be disappointed by the standards of the cooking. Another nice surprise is the wine list. You might imagine that they would try to make money on the wine, but the wines on offer are very good quality and reasonably priced. The one I picked last time was a very good Italian at £26 - it was either the most expensive of 2nd most expensive on the list. Eating in the riverside conservatory is very nice. The main dining room is comfortable and pleasant too - seating is well spaced - not too crowded. Where they need to perhaps improve is on is the consistency of the service. Some visits I've had less than attentive service from grumpy waitresses. One time, in an almost empty dining room I waved at the waitress to get the bill, and she kind of brushed me off and carried on rearranging chairs for the evening session. In my book, sorting out the customer would be a higher priority than prepping for evening service - I was not happy. But on other visits the waiting staff have been fine. They could also do with changing the menu more often.

Bn0eIDhKmkh5a2zlwrSxpQ.text: Gordon Ramsey's Narrow is probably one of the nicest places in the Limehouse area for a summer evening's drink. It also has a very pleasant-looking conservatory for less balmy times. The food is, naturally, very good, though I do object to having to order side dishes separately with main courses. Not only do I dislike having to consider the cost of my potatoes, I rather think one of the benefits of having a professional make dinner is their superior ability to combine ingredients. The service wasn't brilliant, either.

KpviY5y5MVkPURJVygmt8g.text: A place for drinking, not for dining.  It's location is really the only thing going for it.  My advice: grab some chips and onion rings, a few pints and sit outside only on a nice day.  Skip the food and service entirely.  It gets 2 stars for location.  No stars for everything else.My husband and I moved to the area about 5 months ago.  It was time to finally try the narrow, which locals completely disregard.  Now I understand why.When my husband ordered the Narrow Burger he was told that it was ONLY served WELL DONE.  When we scoffed, his sidekick then promptly informed me that "most british burgers are ONLY served well done."  Well, this australian and american know different, much as he might disagree.  Seems that from other reviews, the staff here take pleasure in correcting their non-british patrons.  Apparently, It's a narrow 'tradition.'The burger indeed arrived well done, read: dry.  More like a sausage than a burger. The onion rings made up for it's shortcomings.Other items ordered were nice, but they should've been for the price.  Service was arrogant, until the bill arrived whereby it miraculously improved!  I think we're moving on.

AMEMoqyBe3lB4ey4vzAE0w.text: Was quite happy with a meal here for a large group. A few general tips1) make reservations2) have everyone show up on time3) go on a (rare) sunny day and enjoy the patioWhile some could claim there is too much "Gordon Ramsay halo effect" but I didn't think so. The food was very good (though our group was too large to order off the full menu) and the prix fixe menu we had was well matched and diverse enough for the group's dietary restrictions.The few down sides - the space is not very conducive to waiting at the bar for a table unless it is nice enough for the patio to be used. The service was a little bit gruff, admittedly some parts of the large group were a bit, well demanding - so I'm not holding it against them at this point.

w2VB4TeEK237s7WKYbb5Bg.text: Went out to watch the marathon over the weekend and loved this rare spot to take in a bevvy and soak up the sunshine along the river in - not pretentious - style.  Fave part was the Pimms on tab.  Nicely diced up bits of orange, apple, cucumber with mint.  Who could pass that up?On a crowded day like that we couldn't find a seat, so stood near the flower boxes and toasted the day - didn't stay for the pig roast but the eats looked savory. Next time I'll be sure to make a reso.

8pqDBjf2a_j-1rtkxrRgxQ.text: In The Narrow's favour is it's great location overlooking the Thames on a quiet back street.  Consequently, their are few nicest places in London for an alfresco lunch in the sun.  However, everything else about The Narrow is a bit humdrum.  In common with the other Ramsey gastropubs I have been to, The Narrow has a bit of an identity crisis, unsure whether it is a restaurant which happens to be located in a pub of a gastropub proper.  Consequently, while it is difficult to imagine popping in for a drink at the bar, a few forlorn looking bar stools are available, although I imagine they are mostly used by those waiting for a table.The food is largely standard pub fare - think fish & chips or a burger. These looked pretty good from across the table, although neither dish would be a reason to visit in itself.  I opted for skate, served traditionally with a butter and caper sauce.  This was tasty and showed that kitchen was capable of food which was more stretching than deep frying some fish or grilling a burger.  However, the majority of the menu doesn't allow it to demonstrate this capability which is disappointing.Maybe this place needs a visit from Gordon as while not a Kitchen Nightmare, it could definitely be doing better than it is.

BnKO2cBcPaM_DIPO7n6uSQ.text: Definitely make a reservation, because this place gets busy. Also, ask for a table with a river view if you can get it. We had a great short rib burger, risotto, and steak and ale pie. Our waiter seemed frequently confused and hard of hearing, but it was comical rather than frustrating. If you're a visitor, I would recommend this place for the food, the view, and the quintessential Britishness of the food.

ZABPJHXYFe82XS2-TJlTbg.text: I still can't believe I made it to this restaurant, after getting off the Docklands Light Rail at a random station in East London.  For this Yank, 1 hr from his hotel on Park Lane, this was a bit out of my element.  And while I couldn't get a reservation (despite the restaurant being far less than full), I enjoyed the best fish and chips I'll probably ever have while grabbing a seat at the bar.  And they have trivia night and play Kings of Convenience?  Times like this wishing I was a Londoner...

Jyv75MZbYu_x8jgqxBVIrw.text: Came here yesterday for lunch and had the most amazing fish and chips! It was Beer-battered hake with hand-cut chips and mushy peas served on news paper which was a really nice added touch. The chips were perfection - big, chunky, crispy on the outside and soft and fluffy in the middle.  I had it with the Torrontes which was a lovely light and fruity accompaniment to the fish.The staff were extremely attentive and friendly. My glass was kept topped up and they were really smiley and genuine. The view of the river is great and even though it was a rainy day it was a lovely setting. I imagine this the perfect place to spend a Sunday afternoon - which I will be doing very soon!

PsYnM8y-L0euUWqUJzw3fA.text: Great location by the water, friendly atmosphere but not sure about the street smart thing where restaurants add a compulsory 1 pound surcharge on top of the bill. (ok I know I sound cheap, but I already buy the big issue!).Food was really simple but tasty, although the night I was there they did run out of a few things although it was a Friday night. Perhaps a good sign that things are bought fresh. The place is in the middle of no where as once you are there, it will be "spend the rest of the night there". Recommend for special night out and parties unless you live near by..

SAZfinwg6r7DA1FZMhSZ9w.text: Just wanted to say a big "thanks for nothing" to the waiter that let me order the Soft Herring Roe without anything more than a raised eyebrow and a smirk.Ya might want to be a little bit more descriptive about it next time.  Really.It's the "other" type of egg.  No matter how nutritional or golden seared brown it may be, I'd stay away.  Commence repressing of all memories now.

qnfzKbQnnArFmPMvK_yg-Q.text: Gordon Ramsay quality without any pretentiousness. Great location and awesome casual feel. Staff is fantastic and very accommodating.The menu is simple elevated pub food. We had the haddock and chips and it was a real treat. The beer batter makes a difference and the haddock is super tender. We also order the Cumberland sausage and that was sooo tasty. The dish is drenched in a brown gravy and the sausage is served over mash. Very enjoyable.Had a great experience.

Pa93ea8EONurl26yCwKs2A.text: I work with a bunch of grumbling, finicky people serious about their food and drink, yet our office Christmas meal here escaped the regular sarcasm and disapproving frowns. Carnivores - left happy. Vegetarians - left happy. Wine snobs and beer enjoyers - all glowing and hiccuping. My bosses post-cheque - gave me a little pat on the head for booking an affordable four-course meal that nobody could really be snide about (set menu for the holidays, obviously). Plus the service was exceptional, so I got to sit back and enjoy my meal.True, some complained about the location before we got there but they can get stuffed. You take a train and then a train and oh look, river front meal. The view's lovely, the night was beautiful even though it was raining. In your face.My one and only problem came with booking for a large party. If you're booking for big numbers, you don't deal with the pub directly but go through the Ramsay Empire which I can only guess is located somewhere on the Death Star or similar. Since they're organising hundreds of reservations for all the many establishments sprung fully formed from Gordon Ramsay's substantial forehead, it takes many phone calls and emails just to get them to respond before they give your precious time slot away to some other group of hair-splitting, drunken colleagues. They were nice, but overwhelmed. It wouldn't kill him to hire a few extra Stormtroopers for November and December.

YGcXGTchhXMjbU1KX7PDXQ.text: Location:  The Narrow is located off a main commuter road out of the city and in the midst of the Limehouse district, a well known historic hamlet of merchant houses on the northern side of the Thames.  A taxi from Westminister took 30 minutes at 6:30PM so I'd recommend the high speed ferry to Canary, a short walk.  A true pub atmosphere, the building appears to be a former dock house situated before a small bridge and right on the Thames river.  Walking down a staircase, a diner has the option to enjoy drinks inside or outside or pub grub in an enclosed conservatory or smaller inner rooms. The decor, establishment and service is friendly albeit ordinary which first led me to wonder, why did I come out of the city to dine at a pub?  Once I started reading the menu and tasting the food, I was led to understand this establishment was anthing but ordinary.  The menu could be called, "A Variation on the Theme of Pub Food" as it offers interesting twists and combinations in line with favorite pub creations with a personal twist.  Friends and I shared several dishes.  I will whole heartedly recommend the roast pig and black pudding appetizer followed by the potato cake / duck egg and smoked trout.  The main meals of Toad in the Hole, Hake & Chips and Chicken breast all offered the quality incredients, well prepared flavors and warm flavors one should expect from modern British fare.  Finally we could not resist the opportunity for a Knickerbocker Glory, brownie with ice cream and bread pudding wiht run raisin ice cream.  Spoons down the clear favorite was the bread pudding -  a must try!  It was warm, soft, moist and paired perfectly with custard.   If you're around and about town, don't miss an opportunity to dine overlooking the Thames, dress in casual clothes and post-modern pub grub.

MWPx_ZE3dJ8GNu7-wEhF-g.text: This used to be my local favourite but after our last experience, I wont be returning nor recommending this place. We arrived around 8:30pm without reservations and were seated immediately even though they seemed like they were quite busy.  Not long after being seated, our orders were taken and not long after we had our drinks. I ordered the tortilla fried chicken wings and my fiancée ordered the pea and mint soup. All tasted fine as usual. The chicken was served in a bowl but I was not provided a plate in case I wanted to share or place the chicken bones. I chalked it up to the waiter being busy and I carried on. Then our plates were cleared.  After 15 minutes the waiter came back around and said your mains will be out shortly. We were engrossed in our conversation and carried on talking and talking and talking until I realised hmm, we've talked a lot! It was now quite dark on the patio, other diners who arrived after us were paying for their meals, the large party of 8 seated behind us who arrived after us were happily digging into dessert and even going out to the patio to enjoy an after dinner cigarette.  I got the waiters attention and asked him about our food and he said it was coming shortly. I pressed further noting all the tables around us that had arrived later and were now gone or paying for their meals. After a very pregnant pause, he glanced around nervously and said he'd be right back.  Our food finally arrived (right before we were about to ask for the bill and walk out).  The waiter finally came back and explained that their usual order process was not followed - he had told a colleague to relay the order to the chef and the chef had forgotten and etc etc. basically we got the story of a breakdown of the inner workings of a restaurant rather than an apology.  As he walked us through how the error had happened he promised a manager would come see us and kept glancing at another employee a few feet away who looked like a manager from his non uniform attire and who seemed quite engrossed in our conversation from a distance.  The dress shirt and slacks clad employee listened intently from a distance while polishing silverware but never came closer, nor did the promised manager ever appear. We hurriedly finished our food as we were starving and were offered a dessert menu which we declined just wanting to get out of there already.  The waiter felt so bad that he offered us both a "free and special" dessert which wasn't even one of the desserts in the menu and it wasn't something that could be easily whipped up so I'm not sure where that came from.As our consolation, we were not charged for our mains, only the starters and drinks.I didn't make a bigger deal out of the situation because errors happen, it was a relatively busy evening and I didn't want the poor guy to get fired on my account although he seemed to be pretty slow overall.  What did annoy me and why I won't be returning is that no one took responsibility and if we had not confronted them re the massive wait for the food they would have carried on as if nothing had happened. It took me flagging the guy down and pointing to other people to get the story and my food! The manager who is ultimately responsible for things going awry in the restaurant hid like a coward and never confronted the situation. That's why I will not be returning to the narrow.  Maybe Gordon Ramsay needs to focus less on Kitchen Nightmares in the US and look a bit closer to home.

-XivujVXccl99MqqXKoWTw.text: So disappointed - that's how I felt after a recent trip to the Narrow during a visit to London with the family.  A little back story to explain why I felt this way... while planning this family vacation I insisted that, being in London, I really wanted to eat at one of Gordon Ramsey's restaurants.  Being a big foodie, and fan of Ramsey's, I did my research and decided the Narrow would suit my needs and be budget friendly.  We booked a reservation months in advance and we all happily looked forward to our Ramsey gastropub dinning experience.Upon arrival, we all were pleasantly surprised by the awesome location, but were slightly turned off by the table we were all given directly in the sun, though we figured after a few drinks the sun would go down and we would be fine.  Unfortunately, it took over 20 minutes for our waiter to show up and another 15 for half of us to get the drinks we ordered.  The waiter was extremely scatterbrained, and barely acknowledged us, let alone fulfilled our requests.  After about a half an hour or more, we attempted to place our orders.  That was a disaster.  Everything we wanted, they were out of.... out of fish, out of peas, out of the specials, out of the beer we wanted, etc.  I am not kidding you when I say, EVERYTHING was unavailable, which is ridiculous for a restaurant with like 10 things on the menu.  After expressing our disappointment that we came all the way from the states looking forward to this meal, the waiter scrambled and decided he could get us fish and chips, which is what half our party of seven wanted.  In addition to the mains, we ordered the sausage appetizer.For all the hype Gordon Ramsey has, this food at this restaurant stinks.  The fish and chips was by far the worst we had the whole trip, and the burger was beyond well done and dry.  The only redeeming thing of the whole meal was the sausage, which was a home run, and the ONLY reason I give this place two stars.  I was utterly disappointed in this meal and I hope Ramsey reads these reviews because he seriously has some work to do at this restaurant.  The service was awful and the food didn't even make up for it.  I was totally embarrassed that I forced my family to come to this restaurant as the one things I planned for this family vacation.  It completely changes my opinion of Gordon Ramsey and will probably not go to another one of his restaurants.

sQCIhlbMWBKYvn3wQBzmBw.text: Good, but not great food.  Frankly, after watching Gordon Ramsay's TV shows, I expected better.  Our waiter served our appetizer but forgot our drink order and hadn't even offered water, so the initial course started out "dry".  The fish and chips, touted as the "best" in London, were good (light, crispy batter cooked in hot fresh oil at the right temperature), but not discernibly better than at O'Neils' on Euston, and nearly 2x the price.  The short rib burger was different in a good way, but the bun fell apart altogether too easily and made a mess.  It was served with pickle slices in the sandwich, which I don't prefer, so I had to pick them out.  The chips were good; hot, nice and crispy.  Gordon, you might do well to go in and do a slight makeover for your own restaurant the way you do it on TV for others.  The location right on the Thames is beautiful - right on the water, but it is outside most Central London Underground zones, so we took a taxi from North Central London, which at ~20 GBP one way, seemed a pricey ride for a good, not great dining experience.  To get back, call a taxi or better yet, use the new (free) HAILO app on your smartphone, which vectors the nearest taxi right to your GPS location.

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. The Narrow

nlxWx40S13Q55c7PqClnPw.text: Very slow and unskilled bar service. Peroni was the only lager available and it's served in miniature glasses. The table area was dirty and untidy. Tables weren't clean and used glasses and plates left lying around for hours. A total pigsty.

GK6gQadsx5OE91XYvwwkxA.text: Considering this is a Gordon Ramsay pub, I expected more from the food. Instead my fish finger sandwich was all fancy fancy. When really, all you want from a fish finger sandwich is unhealthy goodness and carbs. Instead I got average (albeit handmade) fish fingers on a rosemary ciabatta. I'm still trying to work out in what world rosemary goes with fish. But it doesn't. To highlight this, exactly the same bun was used on my friends burger. It didn't work with that either. And while the tartare sauce was tasty, it was ruined by throwing a whole load of coleslaw in the bun as well. So what you have is a great bar snack ruined with poshness. The staff are nice here. After my friend managed the spectacularly throw his meal on the floor (we were eating in the bar, on sofas, which wasn't very clever), they kindly replaced his fries when he tried his luck. Actually, there wasn't a moment when the staff weren't friendly and helpful. But we were there all night and they only came to clear the tables around us once. That's not cool. Thing is, we were only here because The Grapes up the road was too busy. I'd only come back here for that very reason.

F6ojwiA0rznATG_4P-fhzg.text: I am beginning to think that Gordon Ramsey is totally overrated.  Was headed to this general hood for a show at the Troxy and was trying to find a last minute place to eat.  The reservations via the web said I had no chance of getting a table but I figured we might be able to eat at the bar.Well, the bar isn't really set up for eating....but luckily there were plenty of tables available.  It is a boathouse setup and I can imagine on a nice summer day around 6pm this place is packed with Canary Wharf bankers.  We could hear the music from the bar at our table and let me tell you, it was a sax playing bad wedding tunes.  Smooth Operator by Sade and other light hits.  Not great ambiance.The food was decent, but nothing to write home about and nothing to scream Gordon Ramsey chef extraordinaire.  The chips with the fish and chips were mediocre at best--I've had much better chips at different less pretentious gastro pubs.  I had some type of braised beef with cabbage and some type of dumpling.  The cabbage just tasted like all of the cabbage I've had recently, and the dumpling was dry and nearly stuck to my mouth.There isn't much in that neighborhood, but I'd try a couple of places I spotted on Commercial Street before ever returning here.@LIzzie, the bread was free.Service was fine, but not great.

bJP8TpMssiwvGkhWmWSitA.text: First things first, the location is awesome - nestled in between the docks with tables right on the river, its cozy and comfortable and offers great views. Sadly, I thought the food was average at best, and both food and drinks were overpriced. Seems like just another place that can take advantage of the view to serve OK food and jack up prices on drinks. Service was kind of weird - seemed like we were more of a nuisance than customers. I had asked my waiter to sub the chips for mash with my fish and chips (where he informed me that fish and chips are a British tradition, thanks captain obvious) so I went with his 'reco' and was disappointed by them as I've had much better for much cheaper.Other dishes I tried - the pork belly and oxtail - were good, but nothing spectacular. My fish was tasty and fresh, but didn't compare to Sausalito's Fish. I'd also say the pseudo-British pub I worked at in Danville might give them a run for their money. I really wanted this place to be a winner on all accounts, but it was kind of a let down in the gastro dept. I also really wanted Gordon Ramsay to redeem his a-hole behavior and reputation from American TV with an excellent dining experience but, that didn't happen either. However, I'll go back, definitely for a drink and the view, especially when it gets warmer and the patio opens up.

JXYUuhCRe9ZNzWm3_COorA.text: Sunday roast and the herring roe on toast is amazing. And they have staropromen on tap.

1sWPOTMdZJ4KiRHUXlpKGg.text: So having relocated from Glasgow to London, this is now my local. What is it with the lack of pubs in Shadwell/Limehouse! Missing a trick there guys...hard-worked commuters need their bevvy more than anyone I would have thought...anyway, in my research about the area I had noticed this and bookmarked it, and have been a few times. What I really like is that you can just go for a drink - silly I realise, but I did genuinely just think it was a restaurant! Furthermore, the patio is brilliant, and it does feel nice and plush to be sitting on actual cushions instead of plastic seats. A very civilised place to have a glass of wine. Also the house white is very nice and good value for money.The food...is pretty damn good. Having only had the fish and chips, I was pleased to see that they used haddock (so sick of cod and 'river cobbler' other places...what the heck is river cobbler?!) and the chips came at least twice-cooked = YUM. However, in my humble opinion the fish should be breaded, as the batter was just soggy, nor did the fact it was beer-battered add any flavour. Plus...and this to me is a bit of a sin...no HP or brown sauce!! Is this a Scottish thing? I'm not sure, but I know that tartare sauce is nice, but is not as POW as HP sauce...Also, inside I found that the windows/blinds could use a bit of a clean, and were quite well-inhabited with spiders and cobwebs...get the hoover and duster out Gordon.Will be back, and will report on what else is on the menu...

2h9sRVqUvE_ycjszoNd-0w.text: The bread was dry as a bone and bland--we knew that was a bad sign.The starters were OK:  burrata is pretty hard to mess up.  The cured salmon was nice, but the accompanying pickled cauliflower had no finesse; my mouth still shudders at the harsh vinegar taste.The pork roast was beyond dry; I had to send it back and choose something else.  The replacement was fish with some kind of boring vegetable medley; unmemorable.Neil had the sirloin roast dinner, which was about the quality you'd expect at any random pub.  The meat was passable, the potatoes, carrots and yorkshires had obviously been sitting around, and the boiled broccoli was bland as can be.Dessert was OK, but I wouldn't order it again because it wasn't worth the calories:  flourless orange and almond cake with crème fraîche.At least they had a Chapel Down wine on the menu.The manager on duty had an open ear to my feedback, but it was disappointing that he didn't seem shocked by everything that had been poor.So disappointing.  We'll stick with Jamie Oliver restaurants.

XItDtYQpN2LY34koeTp_nw.text: Fish and chips was good. They let us have a table, even with our baby. Other places wouldn't let us in with a baby. The service was fast and friendly.

L5l-emJaFj7bdj1y1Lbd8g.text: I am a fan of Chef Gordon Ramsay! I had the lunch set with fish and chips (which come with pea puree) and apple crumble with English custard. Absolutely delicious! The Narrow is a lovely restaurant with very nice view of the river Thames.

ROMWKofLnuUM6abdizL71g.text: Gordon Ramsay gastropub in Wapping with stunning views of Canary Wharf.Quality of food is very good and reasonably priced for a restaurant. Drinks in the pub are a bit pricey. Nice pub quiz on a Monday evening. Don't drive there because ther's nowhere to park.

XkOlCjQsfibbXsnsTNDZrw.text: I was in London with a friend to celebrate her 30th birthday. She loves Gordon Ramsay's restaurants so we of course had to eat at one of them while we were in town. The Savoy Grill is a little out of my price range, so we opted for The Narrow instead. It is a little out of the way, but once we got there we enjoyed every minute of it.They seated us on the patio so we had an excellent view of the river and a perfect sunset. For an app, I got the crab on toast. There was a TON of crab on that toast. It was good, but I don't know about £12 for crab on toast. My friend got the scallops and really loved them.For mains I was really in the mood for a burger, so I went for it. It was very good. Cooked perfectly and really flavorful beef. Totally recommend if you are looking for a burger. The special of the night was a beef wellington so that is what my friend got. How could she pass up the signature dish for her b-day celebration? She loved it.And while we were both quite full from all of the food and wine that we had already consumed, we decided to get some puddings. I got the special which was homemade donuts with a caramel/chocolate dipping sauce. The donuts were ok, but I would be happy to have more of that dipping sauce. My friend won in the battle of desserts with the Knickerbocker glory. I have no idea of what all was in it, but it was incredible. I wouldn't go out of my way to go here, but if for some reason, you are in the neighborhood it is a nice place to grab a meal.

QBk6RNzwqnyXYx5LEe9xjQ.text: Went for dinner, great table in conservatory with direct view of the river, they opened the large windows and the roof and so it was like eating outside.   It was busy and we had to wait quite a long time for our food to arrive.  The quality of the appetisers and main course was very good but we felt the quality suffered due to it being busy.  The wine list choice and price was good, the deserts were not at the same level.  We mentioned to the manager our feelings about food but he did not do anything.   A good restaurant that we enjoy regularly.

aw_zVverpRG3Y1NtvFeRXQ.text: The Narrow is a beautiful pub in a fantastic location, right on the Thames by the Limehouse marina. It used to be a firm favourite for a Sunday afternoon pint or a special meal. However, the recent overhaul has left much to be desired... They only serve 2/3 pints now, which seems a cynical way to ramp up the prices. The outdoor area has been overhauled and feels somewhat more pretentious with the wicker furniture - bring back the picnic tables! The food has always been pretty pricey and a bit hit and miss - I've had some lovely meals but have also had a pasta dish which was so salty I couldn't eat it. The indoor area is, however, gorgeous and the espresso martinis are highly recommended!

UsgphhydX2yyR1juCQsilQ.text: My friend who lives in London insisted that we go get an authentic Sunday Roast at The Narrow, because that is what "true" British people eat on Sundays.  I was a little skeptical, I'll admit, but boy, was she RIGHT!  Sunday Roast is amazing, especially when Gordon Ramsay is in charge!For a very reasonable price you can order one of a few Sunday Roast options...corn-fed chicken (what I opted for), pork and beef.  The beef dinner comes with Yorkshire Pudding, which I know in the states as a popover.  And I really wanted a popover, even though I got the corn-fed chicken.  Unfortunately, they only make enough popovers for the beef dinners (possible, though somewhat unlikely...and something they should remedy immediately and offer as a dinner side for a small additional price...I'd buy two popovers!).The restaurant is nestled on a beautiful and quiet waterway, and is composed of a few small dining/living rooms for the pub area, and then a nice wrap around indoor/outdoor porch.  It's really a lovely spot with great views...just an enjoyable and relaxing way to spend a Sunday in London.  I loved it!

Nbd9nsuiBxDq0LGQOFF-IA.text: The comfort food was delicious, the drinks were satisfactory, the service was good, the view was nice and the ambience was pleasant. Well worth the trip, use maps on your phone for walking directions from Limehouse DLR. Remember to tap out at the station; find an exit gate to do so, else you'll pay a penalty fare.

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom

E_sUt8m8pYaamPM9mQCUrg.text: Fish n' chips + wine + good company = great night of eating and laughing.  I ate here while on a business trip in January.The Narrow is a great stop for traditional English fish and chips. My meal had slightly fried fish that was soft enough to cut with a fork (true test!).  The chips were not too oily and complimented well.  My favorite side was the mashed peas...fantastic taste to go with the fresh fish.Add a bottle of wine and you have a great meal.The restaurant is right on the water and in a residential area, which makes it a more local experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Ahhh...fish, chips, and mashed peas!

SnIgj14r5guO4wbi5sqqmw.text: Friends of ours in London recommended this place and we went with them, treating them to dinner as a thank you for allowing us to stay with them during our visit to the city.  Easy walk from the DLR and Canary Wharf area, with a mix of trendy modernism and classic pub style.  We had drinks in the bar area first while waiting for our table, and then were seated with a view of the Thames.  We got in before it was too busy, but you could tell the place was already getting crowded, but not annoyingly so.  The food was really good.  My wife had a fish dish, and I had a lamb stew that was traditional in style.  The beer was good (mostly typical London style ales).  They also had a rather extensive cocktail menu.The only downside was our server, who while very nice and attractive, seemed a little unsuited for the job and inexperienced.  We didn't stick around for desert or after dinner drinks, deciding instead to walk down the street a bit to The Grapes, a nearby pub with a more traditional atmosphere (smell of fish and chips in the air).

EKnxpzy4cSA-0Q3K5muOTw.text: The food was incredible but I am here to praise the service! It was my moms birthday and she was here visiting on a trip from America. We had booked a table and really wanted a conservatory seat as it was the last day of her trip and birthday. The conservatory was full but they arranged for us to have a drink on the patio and wait till a seat became available for our dinner, and were so kind and understanding and came to the patio no more than 30 minutes later to tell us they'd squeezed us in. Our waitress was so sweet and helped us with the menu - the food came out perfect and we LOVED the artichoke soup starter. THEN my boyfriend needed to print tickets we had ordered online for a boat ride and didn't get to print so the manager came and brought us the laptop to print them!! Honestly we were not the easiest group tonight but they made it so lovely I will be coming here again with my coworkers and friends whenever I get the chance. (And promise to be a simpler customer!) I apologise to the staff if we were a lot of trouble, but you showed what incredible service and staff you have to compliment a perfect menu :)

Ap44MwKr64sH03GBv08zWQ.text: Knowing that we were only going to be in London for two nights and wanting to simultaneously have a Gordon Ramsay/authentic fish and chips experience, we were lucky enough to find this place online.  Thanks, Yelpers! (It was also super lucky that this place was within walking distance of our hotel in the Docklands, so double bonus!)This place had a great atmosphere and I know I would be back for pub trivia on Mondays regularly if we lived here.  They gave us a nice table with a view since it was our first time there and told us that their fish and chips were the best in London.  OK, I'm game, give me that.  Jeremy had the bangers and mash with onion sauce to round out the pub experience.  Both were incredible!  Mushy peas were a little too mushy for J, but I loved 'em.  Fish was crisp but not oily, chips were crunchy on the outside, fluffy on the inside.  Perfect.  Sausages were very filling and rich, but satisfying on a cold night with a bit of a walk ahead of you.  It was also here that I met my new love, Crabbie's Ginger Beer, which I will be searching for in the states.  So sweet and crisp and not too alcoholic for this lightweight.  Love it.Overall its a great little spot not to heavy with tourists.  Nice to get the Gordon Ramsay experience without the four pound symbols.  Try it!

LGfqii76F40YFYMM6kp3wQ.text: We made a reservation here for Thanksgiving dinner, a tradition I'm going to head steadfastly on to even as the American girl inside of me starts embracing words like loo and confusing questions like "You alright?" Yes... I'm fine... I think?Although this Gordon Ramsay site has an amazing floor to ceiling window view of the river and a cozy fireplace in the bar, we found ourselves shivering as the wind blew against the restaurant.  Keep your coat on, it is cold next to the windows.Service was also mediocre, we had to ask several times for a soup spoon, and the waitress was a bit brusque when we asked her questions.We ordered the pumpkin soup, pork terrine, calamari, and peas cabbage and bacon.  The peas was the favorite amongst the starters.  The pork terrine was very salty and we could only finish half of it, the calamari was a bit too chewy, but the pumpkin soup was good... once we got a spoon for it.We ordered the game pie, and Thanksgiving dinner consisted of turkey, cranberry sauce, creamed corn, sweet potato, mashed yams.  The mains were much better than the entrees, but similar to when I went to Ramsay's London restaurant in NY, seasonings were off.  The food was either too bland or too salty.If there is something you shouldn't leave without trying though, it would be the banana sticky toffee pudding with its large morsels of banana hidden between moist cake.  One thing I've noticed in London is that the stick toffee puddings tend to be inedible dough bricks, but it was one thing The Narrow did perfectly.

wLtyVyrqq3s8nVlHP0E3MA.text: The only good thing I can say about our experience at The Narrow is that it is in a lovely setting.  Other than that, it was probably the worst meal I have ever had in a restaurant in my life!  My daughter ordered a chicken plate and I had the sirloin, both of which came with potatoes and carrots.  Horrible!  None of it had any flavor or seasoning at all, and it all looked and tasted like it had been dumped into a pot of boiling water and then served.  I had to "saw" at my sirloin in an effort to cut it--it was so tough and rubbery.  All of the food was rubbery--quite disgusting actually!  The worst part is that it was very expensive--the most expensive meal we had during our stay in both London and Paris!  What a waste!  We will never go back there.  Shame on you, Gordon Ramsey.  Perhaps you should do an intervention on your own kitchen.

DHguZLUMKcgQntN6KLVE6Q.text: Unimpressive. Watched as several (older) patrons got angry about the 2/3 size pint. I agree, just another way to skim. Overpriced for something not extraordinary. Can find the same or better food anywhere for less money. It's just a nice locale. Gordon Ramsay is a tool.

62O2D8UnP4SNb9k8ylsqQg.text: I ate here a year ago, when it was a great neighborhood pub..lots of local beer snd great fish & chips.  Came back tonight with those same thoughts and expectations.  Apparently it is now owned by Gordon Ramsey and what a change.   Frufru beer, upscale menu that just doesn't fit either location and a snobby server attitude. I haven't received my meal yet , so I can't review the food, but based on the less than stellar changes to this once great place, I am not expecting much

OPerE2ou0wKchDeKIYvG0g.text: What a fantastic location on the river!  Let me talk about the site.  There is a downstairs bar area with dining and then an upstairs dining room.  In addition, there is an outdoor "indoor patio" with large glass windows, couches and fireplaces looking out and then for the hard core ,a true outdoors patio with table benches and umbrellas.  But just a brilliant location.I stopped by late one Friday, walking over from Canary Wharf, and set up shop in the bar.  I was a little crusty from the night before, boozing and such and was hungry, but nevertheless it was a pint for me and then fish, chips and mushy peas.  The fish was on target(piping hot), chips OK, and then there were the mushy peas....  I loathe peas to the highest order, in nearly all forms, except split pea soup.  However I didn''t dislike these mushy peas.For dessert the barman suggested the bitter chocolate mousse over the cherry tart.  I went with the mousse- just OK.  I think the tart would have been better.  This is a damn fine location for food and beverages and I look forward to further visits!

qKWB4brDRxqW3s5KkH293Q.text: I came here for my birthday this year with 3 of my friends and we had a fabulous time! Although my special day is in June, the weather wasn't playing nicely and it was monsoon like rain instead of beautiful sunshine so the fab location on the river didn't look as wonderful as it could've, though this didn't dampen our spirits and you could still see how great it looked - the 02, the Shard and the tower down at Elephant and Castle are some of the landmarks to spot.The service was good and the staff friendly and polite. We all ate roast dinners and they were great value, extremely tasty and delicious and very filling. We also enjoyed a lovely bottle (or two if I remember correctly ;-) ) of red and some beautiful desserts - my bread and butter pudding was the envy of the table and we all enjoyed an aperitif too. After this we decided to move into the pub part and have a drink or two there and although a little pricey, as you would expect for a gastropub and not least a Gordon Ramsay one, there was a great atmosphere and I would definitely return and recommend The Narrow.

Y708pW0Gj7NYfchlBWv_vA.text: The Narrow is a beautiful unsuspecting restaurant in the Limehouse area of London.  It looks like nothing from the street but when you go down the stairs, you enter a very beautiful restaurant on the river Thames.We stayed in Paddington so we took the underground to the overground then caught an Uber from the train station to the restaurant.  It was pretty easy and worth the couple modes of transportation.The Narrow is a Gordon Ramsay restaurant.  We knew we wanted to try one while we were in London and quite frankly, it had the best sounding menu and was much more affordable than some other choices.  It was also nice that the restaurant is on the river so you also get beautiful views while you dine.When we entered, we were asked if we had reservations, we said no and the host was very kind and found us an amazing table next to the large windows so we could see the river.  I was shocked we were able to get such a nice table with no reservations.  The host also made conversation with us and was very welcoming.When we sat down we were given menus.  We each ordered a diet coke and some water and bread with butter.  We then decided on fish and chips for our main and sticky toffee pudding for dessert.  We even asked for Yorkshire Pudding to go and they even obliged that!  First off, the bread and butter were great.  The bread was obviously freshly baked and slightly warm.  Our order included four pieces of bread, two of each variety so we each got to try the different types.Next, we had the fish and chips.  I was debating between that and a roast they had that day, mainly because I wanted to try the Yorkshire Pudding but I also really wanted some good fish and chips and I was figuring this restaurant wouldn't disappoint.  It was wonderful!  The fish was so fresh and hot!  The batter was light and crisp with a good amount of flavor.  The chips were prefect.  Crispy yet pillow soft on the inside.  The mushy peas were interesting, just not my thing and the tartare sauce was literally the best I have ever had.  They really need to jar it so you can take some home.  It was awesome!Finally we had decided we wanted to try Sticky Toffee Pudding.  It was served with a salted caramel ice cream.  It was so rich, my sister and I shared it and it was definitely enough for both of us.  It was excellent!Our Yorkshire Pudding was also wonderful!  Light, airy and crispy on the outside.  It was so dang good!The service was impeccable.  The views were beautiful and our entire lunch was delightful.  The restaurant definitely did not disappoint at all!  I would happily return!

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Half of the bread that comes with the bread and butter
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Line caught haddock with chips, smashed peas, house made tartare and grilled lemon

YVmkbg7ixlozjkI0pr2cLg.text: Had dinner here tonight. Bread and butter to start with (not free, but ok). Nice selection of breads, including foccacia, seeded roll, and poppy seed roll. Nice Gloucestershire butter - yum.Had the Camden Pale Ale (just so so) and the London Pride Cask Ale (better than the Camden).Ordered 2 hanger steaks (served with chips and rocket/tomato salad), a side of cole slaw, and the special - ribeye with chips, and rocket/tomato salad, and a side of Caesar salad.All steaks were ordered medium rare. All were what we would consider redder than normal for medium rare. One of the hanger steaks was way, way rare. The peppercorn sauce was good, the chips were very crispy, and good. The rocket and tomato was good. The cole slaw was a bit too creamy/goopy for our tastes (we like ours more lightly dressed). The Caesar salad was good, but also a bit overly dressed. (Maybe a British thing to saturate salads with too much dressing? 3rd restaurant in 3 days that did that)Told the waiter at the end of dinner about the too-rare steak. He said hanger steaks are tough to get right because of the varying thickness of the meat. I don't know about that - had hanger steaks in many places cooked medium rare that were just fine.All in all, nice place, nice atmosphere, good service, food just ok.

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Beers on tap
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Menu - Sept 2018
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Hanger steak - a bit too rare to be medium rare

KIqcQzXPiHAtvcgMwGtp5Q.text: So, this was my first experience at a Gordon Ramsay restaurant and I'll say I was not disappointed.  My sister and I wanted to have a nice lunch so we grabbed a Uber from the overground station.  We arrived just after noon.  We walked in and were asked if we'd made reservations, this hadn't even occurred to us.  We said no and the were told they could give us a table.  We were seated in the covered patio overlooking the water. Menus were brought promptly and our drink orders were taken.   We were then offered bread and butter which we say yes too.  It was a nice start to our lunch.My sister and I both ordered the fish and chips.  The food arrived after about 20 minutes with everything pipping hot.  The fish was fresh and crisp, the fries perfectly cooked. Everything was wonderful and the freshly made tartar sauce was exceptional.  I've never had a better tartar sauce.  We also ordered Yorkshire Pudding to go because we love Yorkshire Pudding and very badly wanted to try some while we were in England.  The server graciously gave us some to take with us.  For dessert we ordered the Sticky Toffee Pudding to share.  It was wonderful.  It was extremely rich and sweet but I thought it was the perfect ending to our meal.  The food was wonderful, service was great and the view beautiful.  If I return to London I would not hesitate to return to The Narrow.

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Sticky Toffee Pudding
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Fish and Chips
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Bread and Butter

aqw4CwZlPKLZmHhQwU29Pw.text: After a day of Royalty and Tea Parties we hailed a cab and headed over to The Narrow! We had never been here before but just looked up restaurants on the water and found this beauty! It was quite a ways from our hotel but was worth the drive for this beautiful setting!We didn't have a reservation so we started out with some drinks and appies at the bar until a table on the patio opened up!The service was great...we asked to order our food family style. They weren't sure what we meant by that but once explained they were very accommodating! We ordered a few mains and some sides to go with...sharing it all! This is such a fun way to sample more of the menu! The Bangers and Mash was very tasty. Had a fun leisurely evening of good food, drinks and much laughter at The Narrows.

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. After dinner Espresso Cocktails...yum yum!

kz1oTh20g-lGYuHTPdIHNw.text: The roast was tough. We were 20 minutes late for our reservation because of a cab driver. Got a lecture from the maitre d' but graciously (sarcasm) seated us anyway.  Ruined what had already turned into a stressful evening. The waitress arrived to tell us the we needed to order right away because the kitchen was closing. Understand we had an 8pm reservation and arrived at 8:20.  The food was generally good but not great. Mr. Ramsey needs to check up on his own establishments rather than worrying about how others run theirs. Won't return and won't recommend to others.

kdsSH5TDH2MpPGXXXgZP5w.text: I absolutely loved my experience here. We had the best wine and we started with salmon appetizer as well as the board followed by the ribeye steak special. Loved this place. Best service we had on our two week U.K. Trip! And Alicia was fabulous!

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom

aI6AGpinBRwhOl47p3lZow.text: Dining with friends that live in the Canary Wharf area all were excited to try a Ramsey restaurant for the first time. The dining experience was a disappointment. Slow service from the waitstaff could be from an understaffing problem for the night. The best thing about the restaurant was the location on the water. Prices were exorbitant, quite shocking. The food was just ok and  lackluster to what we had anticipated.

4uuNQBwhMqPldS54vOP4cA.text: Was with some friends who were excited to try a Gordon Ramsey restaurant.  Well, this evening was less than stellar.The maitre'd greeted us with what I felt was ambivalence, but was accommodating to seat our party of sic without a reservation.Server was generally good, but far from outstanding.  I had the Barbary duck with lentils.  Even though tasty, the duck was tough and difficult to cut through. The fief and chips were generous with a side of mushy peas.  Once again, ordinary, better fish and chips elsewhere, just nit enough flavor.  The peas were bland, could have used salt, mint, anything.Won't be returning to another Ramsey restaurant anytime soon.

EpfUa0E51VeP-T2d6jPmfA.text: By far the best fish and chips we had in London. The drinks were awesome and the wine list was extensive, fair priced and good. There are three of us together and all of us have different ratings two with four stars and one with five stars, so the average is 4.33 stars. Not a lot of room for improvement, but I guess everyone can improve. Great place to sit on the Thames and watch the world go by. A lot of good famous people watching in this place... We saw one in particular while we were here. The bathrooms are very nice and clean and the service staff are very sweet and competent.

H8rcuvDaXPveEsZtAjISHQ.text: This is tough because the service was fantastic, I mean really goo, the waiter who looked after us for the evening did a really great job and he was badly let down by his kitchen colleagues.The starter was by far and away the highlight of this meal, smoked salmon with a citrus fennel salad, very light and spring like...its winter....its cold and I want something more punch, beetroot would be better IMHO does a couple of different ways.Main was meant to be west country rib eye steak with mash potato and a green peppercorn sauce...yum I thought. When you cook rib eye you have to get it on a very high heat to sear it and break down the sinew that surrounds the eye otherwise the steak is a bit limp, fatty and chewy...well guess what I was served. The supposed medium rare was very rare and as it hadn't seen a hot pain the fat was stringy and not pleasant. The mash was non-existent...instead supermarket chips and the peppercorn sauce was a rather lacklustre gravy.The desert was a pear and berry crumble, pleasant enough but the fruit was undercooked and the clotted cream ice-cream underwhelming. Gordon Ramsay put his name to this place!!! Not sure what he has been up to as they are having a real kitchen nightmare! Celeb chefs cant expect punters to pay based on their name if the food isn't going to match up to the price!

fejOnRqlQvOt_3_PpqXKoA.text: Location says it all. Beautiful view of Canary Wharf on the left and The Shard on the right.Service is very important to me and everyone at The Narrow deserve 5 stars for their attentiveness and professionalism. They were quick, polite and very patient (especially with 2 people in my party that were very demanding)There are 2 reasons I rated The Narrow 4 stars:1: First batch of breads were cold and stale (the second one was good)2: The panna cotta was not set properly, it was runny, not creamy...Best dish: The Hanger steak!

t0jU2We5uZXmfxyjkXSdyw.text: I've lived in the Limehouse/Canary Wharf area for three years now and finally made my way to The Narrow last weekend for what I thought would be a nice Saturday afternoon lunch.Before I say anything else, The Narrow is a beautiful pub. It's situated right on the Thames and has a gorgeous light and bright interior. You can see the Shard from the window and watch boats pass by - it's a very lovely place to sit on a sunny afternoon.Now, on to the food. This is where things started going south for me. I knew going into The Narrow that this was going to be pricier than your average pub (Gordon's got to make his money somehow). I was still a bit surprised, however, when I ordered a bowl of chowder for £7 and was presented with a tiny ramequin of cloudy salt water filled with celery. Let's just say I wouldn't recommend ordering the soup.In an attempt to eat somewhat healthily, I also ordered a 'side of greens.' What I got was yet another tiny ramequin of boiled kale. It wasn't seasoned. It wasn't even cut up! It was just gigantic rubbery leaves of kale. My boyfriend order the lamb, and while it was admittedly better than my cloudy water and leaves, it was as close to flavourless as lamb allows. The broth was really thin and the vegetables were bland. This is not what you'd expect for £18.50.Will I be back? Not for the food. I might come back next summer when the weather is nice to enjoy a pint by the river. I may even spring for a side of chips, but I definitely will not be ordering any more entrees.

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Chowder and "greens"
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Table settings

KC0MHwMs2J0YIwjP2Uz67g.text: Went on the hottest day of the year so far for our anniversary dinner. The location is amazing, right on the river. I have to say, the food and drinks were delicious and pretty reasonable. The ricotta filled gnocchi was a personal fav!! Only reason it doesn't get 5 stars for me is the service. The waiter was perfectly pleasant but unfortunately they were pretty understaffed and we ended up waiting a rather long time to order both food and drinks and our drinks didn't arrive until we had basically finished our starter! Other than that it was really great and would recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Most delicious pudding at The Narrow!

vkCLdGGp0IJx9dIexXZiyw.text: Expensive for what it is. You pay for Ramsey's salary and it's definitely closer to Pub than Gastro. I won't go back there even though the staff was nice and the food OK.

RVxviXabRn5_i5vzu4cd0A.text: Great food, service friendly staff, Good wine selection and British beer.  The river views are fantastic.

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom

R42L9yeW_ON7APnZ8dVbOg.text: The Narrow is a bit out of the way, but sometimes that works to the benefit of a place, as I think it does here. Stopped in here for the first time a while ago, on Easter Sunday when they had an optional set course for the holiday, but I have been back for the regular menu as well. The upstairs is a bit quieter, and the view is lovely, although we did end up waiting about a half hour for the bill once, which may be less likely downstairs. The food itself was fine. I think we went in with expectations which were met, but not exceeded. Basically, for the price bracket, it is as it should be. The roasts were particularly good, and portions generous. There is also a nice bar, and outdoor seating for those few months when that might be toerable.

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. Outdoor area

nOk8KVSNnY4OUqjtvt1Mng.text: We made a reservation for last weekend and it could not have been a more perfect day to come to The Narrow. It was amazing weather to enjoy their patio dining that overlooks the river. Reservations are a must as they looked very busy. The asparagus appetizer was refreshing and had a delicious whole grain mustard vinaigrette. The grilled sole was perfectly cooked and slightly crispy with a really yummy parsley butter. I really wanted to try the Minted pea soup with ham hock and cheddar croquettes. Maybe next time!Wye valley asparagus with radish, lambs lettuce and vinaigretteWhole grilled lemon sole, parsley butterThe Narrow short rib burger, Monterey jack cheese, bacon, skinny chips

3QX4PZcKKmXVbRp8OfKQiA.text: Oh dear.My friend and I went to The Narrow, and right from the off, the service left much to be desired. We were stood waiting for a good 5-10 minutes before our presence was even acknowledged by the staff. And then when we were seated, the waitress just dropped a couple of menus on the table and wandered off, not to be seen again until we ventured away from our table to find someone who would be so kind to take our order for us. We kinda got the impression that we weren't the kind of people they wanted around..And then the food. The asparagus was too hard, the duck egg tasted... not good. And my main course - a lamb rump - was more like lamb rubber. Considering Gordon Ramsey puts his name to this establishment, this was a huge disappointment.After settling the bill, which was extortionate for what the meal and service was, we left The Narrow. And will never be returning.

AM9y42k6AC8Z4HzRcJwd1Q.text: I have a picure of us at the Narrow I cant wait to upload!I live in the US and found the Narrow which was not too easy but well worth it. The staff treated us so well, good drinks, great atmosphere and good food. I love the view and the location at the banks of thames, wishing to go back to London this year and will absolutely return to the Narrow!

photos.caption: Photo of The Narrow - London, United Kingdom. The narrow

7-s9bgsEKaY0anmj9Hz_EA.text: I came here for a work event one evening and found it to be really nice. It's right on the river, so you get a beautiful view and nice cool breeze. The atmosphere is laid back but sophisticated. Their wine list is pretty vast and the food was wonderful. The service was attentive enough and didn't leave anything to be desired for. I would definitely come back to enjoy a nice sunny afternoon or evening.
